author: Christian Nicholas

text: I'm not being racist HA HA HA HA HA HA !!!!!
author: Louis Claudel

text:
You're right it does, the reason behind this might be due to the similar singing traditions of spiritual groups in Asia that has been seeping into one another for thousands of years. The song seems to have more roots in Hindu music with a bit of Pacific-Asian influence to me though.

To be more particular, the song is somewhat based on a folk song from south east asia - an area that boasts a significant Muslim population. The word "Seroja" is a translation of lotus from Malaysian.

In any case, Muslim is not a race :P.
author: Ric Cahn

text:
Thinking this sounds like a "Muslim chant" isn't racist, it's an innocuous opinion.

Preceding any sentence with "I'm not being racist but..." will definitely make you seem racist though.

author: PsychadelicoDuck

text: It's not a stock sound clip, actually. The lyrics in this song are from a famous Malay folk song called Seroja. If I recall correctly, Spyro 2's Colossus theme is just random chanting and not actually a language. EDIT: Omg I just re-listened the Spyro song, and op is right. The lyrics are literally the exact same snippet of Seroja that this song uses. My mind is blown.
author: Duster

text: @Sam Hartman¬†It's not the same clip, though, right? ¬†Says something interesting about human language that me and Will Nye recognized the song, despite being sung fairly differently in the two songs, and not knowing the language (I'm assuming Will Nye does not understand Malay. I apologize if I'm mistaken).
author: PsychadelicoDuck

text: @PsychadelicoDuck¬†You're correct, it's not. The vocalists themselves sound very different, and the melodies are slightly different, too. I couldn't tell you if he speaks Malay or not, but I sure don't, so it really is amazing.

author: Raghnal

text: Thank you for the info!
author: CiaraElizabeth0

text:
For those who wonder what the lyrics are; it is:
"Mari menyusun.... mari menyusun.... mari menyusun seroja.. bunga seroja"
It is in malay/indonesian (you can search Mari Menyusun Bunga Seroja to hear the original song.)

Seroja means lotus and bunga means flower. Mari means let's. Menyusun means arrange.
So the literal meaning is: "Let us arrange lotus flower."

It is fitting indeed, as Astaroth (second battle) is sitting in lotus stance.

author: XxMasterShad0wxX

text:
One of the best tunes in this game and in RPG music altogether. 

A shame the Shadow Hearts series has been put to bed. I doubt we'll be seeing any further entries, but it was fun while it lasted. A shame the Director's Cut of Covenant never came overseas though. What is up with that?
author: Flegan777

text:
One of the the most prominent characteristics of this video game's soundtrack was the ability to portray a kickass sound that got you into it, while at the same time conveying how sad the situations that triggered the battles really were.

Behind it all, Covenant had quite a sad tone, still that didn't mean it had to be a dull experience. The Shadow Hearts series was part of the last bastion of games from the Golden Age of Rpgs that was the SNES/PS1/PS2 era.

text: @robbyalp You should pick the 3rd one up as long as you're not expecting it to be as good as the others. Pick it up as if it were separate from the series. It's an amazing game that gets a lot of crap just because it wasn't as good as the others but it's still a fun and amazing game that everyone should play whether you're a fan of the series or not. Just don't get your hopes up too high and you'll enjoy it more than most rpgs.

text: It's the most American-friendly RPG, actually gets advertising, is always pretty when released, and requires little brainpower to enjoy. Also some people(Mainly the producers) are a little tense about the religious themes used in Shadow hearts and many other RPG series, which basically just leaves Final Fantasy, and "maybe" Dragons Quest as comfortably marketable games, and dragon quest is less serious than FF, which makes it appeal less to people. Sucks, but what can you do other than buy more.

text:
Well, it's very difficult to translate, but it's a type of flower named Seroja, it's a kind of a pastime activity for the women of Javanese background. A sort of flower arranging activity.

author: Ahmed Shafique Mohd Shariff

text: Yeah, Iknow this coz I'm a Malay.
author: Ahmed Shafique Mohd Shariff

text:
If you guys liten to it carefully, it is a Malay/Javanese song titled Seroja. It's a song meant for young virgins towards her adulthood. I'm quite surprised to hear this song on a Japanese game!

The lyrics:
"Mari menyusun Seroja bunga Seroja"

Thesong itself are 3:35 mins but this song however, just use the lyrics there.
author: Ahmed Shafique Mohd Shariff

text: I fell in love with this song, the minute I heard it. Dark, worldly and mysterious. It just screams Shadow Hearts (and Yasunori Mitsuda) to me. :D
